comments.commentBody: Strangely enough, DMV offices are not typically located in fashionable residential neighborhoods. The office I frequent, since they closed the one in Englewood, is in Lodi, NJ. In the 2000 census the median household there was $43,421. Service there is excellent, and if you avoid the end of the month and lunch hour the waits are minimal.

Applications for H1A visas are down to the lowest levels ever. They place many resrictions and demands on the farmers who want these people. But the farmers have decided that they don't want to provide housing and medical care, Porta-Johns and meals in the fields as well as transportation between house and field. It's much cheaper and easier to employ illegals.

No, the established facts say that they are taking American jobs -- the jobs of the working poor. Have you checked out unemployment levels in the ghetto lately? The illegals often work below minimum wage and without labor law protection and off the tax rolls. There is no way that American citizens can compete.

1. You say "Work most Americans can not or will not do." Americans used to do these jobs and will again. Americans cannot compete with the wages and labor practices illegal immigrants will put up with.

2. "The GOP plays the story like some biblical sin." There are MANY non-members of the GOP that have great concerns about what illegal immigration has and is doing to this country, especially the lower classes. The US cannot take in all of the world's poor; the US would double (triple/quadruple even?) in population almost overnight if everyone who wanted to come here was allowed in. Where does it stop? I would like someone (NYT Editorial Board, how about you for once?) to speak to this concern.

These immigrants do not come here just because they like being demonized, treated with disdain, despised by a particular group with a political persuasion, or because they just want to.

The great majority of them come here for work. Work most Americans can not or will not do. Work such as harvesting the citrus crops, field crops that can not be processed by machine, in the fields at daybreak, work until dark, paid by the basket, bushel, or pound, in the the heat, many times 100º and more. Living in four man rooms, following the crops, or cutting up chickens on an assembly line, bloody and greasy. they also work as motel maids, house cleaners, gardeners, pick and shovel laborers, dishwashers, busboys/girls, short order cooks, mean nasty jobs.

Th GOP plays the story like some biblical sin. They crossed some man made border for a better life, and are regarded as little better than criminals, while committing a minor misdemeanor. They also play to those who had to wait to immigrate, when what is needed is seasonal work permits so they can return home when the job is done.

It is a political gain for the GOP, and a loss for the rest of us.

They do the menial work that first generation immigrants have always done. But propagandists tell us they are taking American jobs, getting welfare, overloading our schools, whatever thy can dream up to get rid of the immigrants.

Aside from feral cats - I won't even comment on Marshall's mother's behavior - I see the underlying cause of native species extinction as primarily habitat loss and secondarily lack of ability to adapt to that loss. I suspect the dense suburban environment I live in does not support Eastern Bluebirds but is perfect for House Sparrows (I don't know, would bluebirds build nests in the top of the "e" of the Jewel food store sign?), and yet the America Robin, a native species, has adapted well to our lawns and gardens, appears to be doing very well building nests in garage roofs, over entryways, as well as in trees. I have too many House Sparrows this year, although last year it was House Finches that outnumbered them. I don't "manage" it. Starlings are less attracted to my backyard wildlife habitat. But I rarely see House Sparrows in wilder or more natural areas, and when I do it's only a few on the perimeter, close to human habitat.

Also I have read the House Sparrow is believed to have originated with the pharoahs' grain stores in ancient Egypt, so they have been following us around for a long time. And on the subject of nest predators, I recently watched a Cornell video presentation on Crows by Kevin McGowan: toward the end he showed a pie chart based on studies sampling several areas to determine who were the top nest predators. Believe it or not, Fox Squirrels are the biggest slice and Crows are a mere smidgen.

P.S. Ironically, House Sparrows are in decline in England.

Speaking as a professional driver for 10 years now, the last 3 of which have been as an Independent Contractor, or IC for short, this article hits the nail on the head.  Let us begin with the numbers...  if Bob Costello is correct, and drivers are averaging 8000 miles per month, this works out to 96,000 miles per year.  Furthermore, if average salary equivalents are correct, $40,900.00 per year equates to $0.426 per mil e, rounding up to $0.43 per mile.  This seems like a reasonable wage, right?  These numbers span the entire industry, and do not represent large or mega-fleet trucking companies, who collectively represent  approximately 40% of the industry as a whole.  These companies hire an overwhelming majority of new drivers, and lose almost every one of them within the first year of hire.  If you're curious, look up truck driver turnover in your favorite search engine.  From my own personal experience, I was hired by one of these companies(who paint their equipment orange, by the way) in November of 2003, and stayed until August of 2011, when I purchased my own semi-tractor and went into business for myself.  I was hired as a company driver paid $0.28 per mile, and ran an average of 125,000 miles per year for the next 5 years.  I ran dry van freight, by far the most common type of trailer out there.  I didn't break $40,000.00 until I had been driving for 5 years with this company.  I'll continue in a new comment...
The logging industry may be curtailed in some places, but it has not been eliminated.  It's all around me.  But I agree that we need jobs.

I'm comfortable with the term socialist, especially since I admire the social programs of Nordic countries. Communist, not so much since I associate it with Soviet style central planning.

I'm not sure how I would describe China. Looking at wealth distribution, especially the poverty in western China, I would not describe them as socialists. On the other hand, modern China has clearly moved away from the kind of central planning that hamstrung Soviet Russia. I don't know how to categorize China in the 21st century.

Here's a link that shows how far this lie has traveled:

http://mediamatters.org/research/2014/06/16/right-wing-media-ignore-iraq...
Thank you  for this documentation.

For years right wingers have advanced the falsehood that President Obama did not push for the Status of Forces Agreement. Even Douthat appears to believe this lie.

Here's what really happened:

"In one of his final acts in office, President Bush in December of 2008 had signed a Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) with the Iraqi government that set the clock ticking on ending the war he’d launched in March
of 2003. The SOFA provided a legal basis for the presence of U.S. forces in Iraq after the United Nations Security Council mandate for the occupation mission expired at the end of 2008. But it required that all U.S. forces be gone from Iraq by January 1, 2012, unless the Iraqi government was willing to negotiate a new agreement that would extend their mandate. And as Middle East historian Juan Cole has noted, “Bush had to sign what the [Iraqi] parliament gave him or face the prospect that U.S. troops would have to leave by 31 December, 2008, something that would have been interpreted as a defeat."

http://world.time.com/2011/10/21/iraq-not-obama-called-time-on-the-u-s-t...

Bush signed off. Prime Minister Nuri al-Maliki refused to sign a new authorization in 2011 because the Shia majority and Iran demanded all Americans leave. Without a signed SOFA, US troops had no legal immunity from local prosecution and thus would have been put in an unsafe and untenable position.

Obama wanted to leave a residual force in Iraq. The truth is, we were kicked out.

There is more to this than economics. Mothers who stay at home with infants are likely to have stronger bonding with their child. Giving parents and their babies are more secure start with dividends in areas that are far harder to measure than money and job titles. It comes down, in part, to what sort of society do we want to have: one that values people and uses objects or the other way around?

As things stand with unpaid family leave, while it is available in principle to everyone, in practice it is a luxury few can afford. Once again, the working poor and the middle class are left behind while their better off managers and CEOs can fret and wring their hands about the opportunity costs but truly have a choice to stay home and care for their infant or their dying relative. For the others, it is just the illusion of a choice.

Gee, I wish I lived in a country that valued human beings more than it valued profit. This is just one more way in which demonstrate our shallowness and indifference to quality of life.

Grover lives in Yamhill County Oregon. His parent were dirt poor agricultural workers. The family lived in migrant housing most of the year on different local farms. Occasionally they spent weeks at a time living in tents at a local state park. Grover dropped out of high school after 10th grade.

Grover started pumping gas when he was 14. He's now 62 and still pumping gas for a living. He never married. Lives in an apartment near his job. Grover doesn't drink or smoke, in fact he workouts at the gym three nights a week. Grover keeps to himself. He's well spoken, kind hearted, and is excellent at his job.

Grover is proud of the life he's made for himself. I shared this column with him. His response was it hits too close to home. It's too real. He made it out of poverty, but his brother and two sisters never did. Agreed, we could use a little more empathy in this country. We all need it.

Ah yes, the argument that if everything is owned by someone then property rights will ensure global hygiene. The problem is that there will always be some sliver of the the environment that someone doesn't own, and that sliver will be a dumping ground for private interests. Big companies are always looking for rent-seeking opportunities, and they will find them faster than any libertarian model can assign ownership to every piece of the world.
Sixth?

In no particular order.

First, Iraqi Kurds are mostly sunni, as compared to commie Kurds for example. Americans politics, is it allergic to facts that can't be folded into a two hour summer blockbuster plot with a clear moral?

Second, the Kurdistan issue is not a nice stable package as touted. Syria, Iran, turkey, among others, are involved. Iraqi Kurds prove the " that is just the way those people are" is nonsense because of their radical changes since the gassing and no fly zone. Lesson, nation building is long term and not simple.

Third, the suggested attacks on ISIS now are indistinguishable from those possible before. Tactically nothing's changed.

Fourth, al Sistsani, Persian born, is a Shia, a great man who advocates for an Iraqi nation with sunni as equals. This opportunity is being squandered.

Fifth, the Kurds were recently playing games using ISIS to their advantage to take land and oil. It was as foolish as Maliki. They should not be rewarded while pretending they are what they are not. What they are is good enough.

Seventh, no strategy had yet been declared. America has the power to advance its vital interests. It does not have the best for all power. The greatest fear that American use of force is always bad seems to be held by the Obama administration and the many others who think morality and good rise from american refusal to use force and bad is caused by its use of force. Ask Taiwanese, Koreans, even Vietnamese. Right war? Sheesh.

The Republicans, you are correct, will jump all over that personal profile and cite the "mistakes" made and blame the person for the lack of successfully establishing a sustained, decent life. There is an element of truth in such criticism (we all must take responsibility for our lives), but the problem is that it doesn't go far enough. I think Mr. Kristof selected this person because he likes him as a friend and knows him to be quite intelligent, apart from his educational background. One reason, by the way, that poor people self medicate with drugs and alcohol is the lack of alternative forms of medication (health insurance did not cover mental problems before Obamacare came along) AND the inability to see clearly how they got in the mess they are in. Like most of us, the poor, tend to take too many cues about behavior from the people around them, learning from bad example how to continue in the same direction.

Having undiagnosed ADD in the era before it was fully discovered and understood could be one starting marker for difficulties and eventual failure.

What we need to understand, further, is that poverty and defeat tend to be a downward spiral that can be set off by just a few events (the man in question had a series of really serious problems: mother's sudden death, abandonment by father, ADD, etc.). If one has money, mistakes or difficulties don't matter as much. Without funds, the world pulls people down easily, quickly.

http://terryreport.com

You need a second declaration of war? It would be easy to re-commit to the 2002 authorization, except for one thing: the air strikes target one genocidal group to avert a 21st Century holocaust.  The US Air force can make quick work of ISIS, and I hope it does!
I believe the 2002 authorization for use of military force in Iraq is still in effect. There is also the rather open ended authorization of 2001 against "terrorism."
The ISIS controlled areas are a country with an officially recognized government?

Bombing a country is an act of war

Article 1 section 8 of the US constitution:

"The Congress shall have power to declare war, grant letters of marque and reprisal, and make rules concerning captures on land and water;"

The motivation of the founders was to prevent the President from being able to unilaterally commit the Nation to war without consent of governed as expressed by their representatives.

Amazon makes lots of money from the stuff it sells (including ebooks) and then chooses to reinvest that money in expansion and new ventures. It is not true at all that it loses money on its operations, even though it does not overall show a profit. Now whether you or the shareholders think that is a wise way to run the business is another matter.

Yes, what is wrong about the public having access to books at a price they can afford?  I can afford any and all books but Amazon gives me a quick choice of many books and delivers them immediately.  I am a fan of Amazon and respect their ideas of exposing all peoples to read books anyway they can afford to read.

This is not about shareholders but the customers that could not afford to read books in the past because of pricing.  It creates a path for almost anyone to have the pleasure of reading only because of the pricing that they might not have if not for Amazon.

Amazon has been losing money for almost 20 years now.  They sell goods below cost.  The more goods they sell, the more money they lose.  They lose even more money on shipping stuff to you.  This bizarre folly has been enabled for nearly two decades now by the shareholders, who seem to envision an endless supply of Greater Fools.  Of course, many consumers react to this "business model" with a sort of craven glee.  Who among the simple minded wouldn't love a company that is willing to sell you stuff below cost?  Even Duane Reade and Gristede's might become beloved institutions if they operated in like fashion.  The problem is, a substantial cohort of Amazon's customers are abject cheapskates, who have been trained to expect to buy goods below wholesale. These will be the first rats off the ship when Amazon is finally forced by their shareholders into attempting to make a profit.  Amazon lost $126 million last quarter and the shareholders finally punished them for it, dropping the share price 10%.  In inevitable consequence of their race to the bottom, Amazon's vision of itself has begun to founder, hence the querulous, nearly hysterical tone of this specious and illiterate assault upon the long dead Orwell, of all people.
By volunteering you are already doing more than many who simply complain. Showing empathy and taking action to assist, to mentor, to organize, and to vote can only help. Keep it up.
I am going to add that plenty of wealthier people decline the opportunity to get to know people of lesser means, and to witness their issues firsthand, when that opportunity arises.

It's rare that someone of Mr. Kristof's status actually knows someone like Rick Goff and the others from Yamhill mentioned here. I think that is a huge part of the problem. Empathy is difficult if not impossible if you know no one who is facing these problems; most middle and upper class folks have no substantive contact with the poor. They only know them very superficially as their servers in restaurants or day care workers or house cleaners or the pool guy, which are not personal relationships. And it's the same for most folks in government too. The poor rarely if ever lobby their Congresspersons.

I stil live in the rural area where I used to teach, and now I volunteer at a food bank and an animal sanctuary. I have come into contact, and gotten to know, people living in poverty through these work places, and I understand that they are as human as anyone else. Even though they have limited resources, often of all kinds, they want the same things as any of us--a stable, comfortable life, a good future for their kids and grandkids.

I'm not sure what to do about this.
Sonny, you omitted to add that he was also responsible for 9/11.

Except he did it in every country in the Middle East. He empowered radical Islam and created power vacuums everywhere. He armed Iran with a nuclear weapon, appeased Russia into warlike belligerence, sold out Israel, and has generally made the world an unsafe place.

" this destruction of our democracy must end..."

Obama's trashing of the Constitution, you mean.

The problem with such an analysis is that ethnic cleansing and atrocities such as Bosnia, Rwanda, Darfur, etc. will occur if the US does not help. As Obama stated, we can't always act, but where we can with limited aims, we should.
Sorry about the typo...should have been 'life'.

The class war is never over. As long as capitalism, the parasitic exploitation of the many of the few, continues on it's predicatable course of enriching the 5% whilst perpetually immiserating the majority, bribing the middle, as Marx and Engels so dramatically described in the Communist Manifesto, various imperialism's propel themselves to war, the "gravediggers" are created worldwide, brought into often miserable existence, like Rick, but others educate themselves to eventually overthrow the system and replace it with socialism, the only solution to this problem. Look at the People's Republic of China's journey from a pre-feudal peasant poverty society to the world power today.

Empathy is not a virtue in the Capitalist Religion. Social Darwinism dictates that the rich must pray on the poor, obtain even greater riches, and demonize their pray. Buzz phrases like "personal responsibility" are part of the plutocrats propaganda machine that constantly portrays the downtrodden as lazy and as "takers" while never failing to extol the virtues of the "job creators".

The class war is over. The poor and middle class never had a chance. All that is left is for the winners to create more and crueler ways to exploit the losers. Greed trumps empathy every time. Welcome to the Plutocrat States of America.
Follow the money to the MILITARY INDUSTRIAL CABAL in ANY COUNTRY and the PUPPET POLITICIANS THEY OWN .    Cordially,   D.J. Ludwig
Does any bank really keep $430,000,000 in cash?????

Obviously David there are several who gain. Israel expects to gain if its Arab neighbors disintegrate. Saudistan and UAE gain if relatively liberal Arab regimes such as Lebanon and Jordan are no longer around to make them look bad. US gains because it can easily dominate the resulting collection of warlord ministates, and no longer face obstreperous regimes like Syria and Iraq.

We are witnessing the unintended consequences of several flawed foreign policy decisions, of presidents past.
The decision buy Eisenhower to eliminate Mohammad Mossadegh in Iran, stopping a democratic government, and bringing about an Islamic state hostile to the U.S.

Then the most recent, the appointment of J. Paul Bremer, as ambassador plenipotentiary to Iraq, a right wing ideologue, with no knowledge of the Middle East, the Arab World, the differences between Sunnis and Shiites; who destroyed the educational system, the military leadership, the public service, in an attempt to build a nation as the demon on his shoulder G.W. Bush allowed him to do.

He removed all the Sunnis from any and all positions, and now they are working to take the country back as it was. Now there is no one to obstruct ISIS except the Kurds, and they have been given short shrift to appease al Maliki.

The Kurds are the best force in the area, but they need technical help with armored vehicles, artillery, and air support in some cases.
Iran is also opposed to ISIS, and we can use that to get more cooperation from it.

We need to identify where ISIS is getting their funding, and put a stop to it. None of these forces can fight battles if they can not buy ammunition and weapons.

We can shut down their bankers, freeze their funds, and put countries that finance them on the no bank list.

The people of Europe would be surprised to learn that they did not sacrifice during both World Wars. They repaid the Marshall Plan. It was not a gift and they endured the Cold War battle of nerves to a greater extent than we did.

We chose to be the world's police force. No one forced it on us and we do so only where it protects the interest of our corporations. Just ask countries with no valuable natural resources.

To continue, it wasn't until I switched to a more specialized career, hauling liquid chemicals in 7000 gallon tanker trailers that I surpassed $0.38 per mile, moving on up to $0.43 per mile, but running only around 105,000 miles per year, mostly due to all of the hours spent loading and unloading liquid chemicals, which does take longer than dropping off one trailer and connecting to another in a large parking lot, at least if you don't want to explain to the customer, the trucking company, and the local police why the water from the river is non-potable.  I still averaged 5 days at home per month, and continued to watch my social life wither and die.  Two years later, I was making $0.44 per mile, still running 105,000 miles per year, and the company informed us that the pay structure had changed, and future raises would be strictly "performance-based", which meant that effectively my pay was capped.  For those that may be asking "Why can't you work harder?"  The trucking industry is governed by the Federal Motor Carrier Safety Administration, or FMCSA for short, which is part of the Federal Department of Transportation.  The regulations that drivers operate under split our time into 4 categories:  1:Off-duty(Driver has no responsibility for equipment or freight, and is away from the vehicle)  2:  Sleeper Berth(Driver is in the attached sleeper cab)  3:  On-duty Driving(Driver is operating the vehicle)  (I'll continue in the next post...)

Israeli Air Force should bomb ISIS instead Gaza.

It would lower human suffering in both cases.

@Bryan-
"The question for you to ponder is; would you believe any statement from Hamas terrorists relevant to the security of the Nation of Israel or the Jewish people? "

I don't need to ponder it. I look at facts instead of propaganda.

For instance, the Fatah politicians you refer to was one Fatah security officer and that was in 2007.

http://www.haaretz.com/news/palestinian-gunmen-target-haniyeh-s-home-in-...

You may recall that, in April, Hamas and Fatah signed a "unity" agreement and minutes after Israel bombed Gaza on some pretext.
